  • Revamped my resume and LinkedIn profile

     Jan 17, 2017

    I've been reading that book on nailing the PM interview and have been picking up ways to improve my resume. I decided to completely redesign the layout, rewrite the copy and I added a references section.

    I also met with my mentor, Seda, today at BunkerLabs and told her about my ambition to land a job as a Product Manager. She gave me a lot of great advice and told me that in addition to redoing my resume that I needed to update my LinkedIn. So I did.

    I'm ready to start applying for PM positions and have already started writing cover letters. Lets go!

  • New client with a livestreaming player

     Jan 15, 2017

    I got a new client today; a company called 4DWW. They do live web broadcasts and web meetings.

    My job is to build them a webpage that has a live streaming video player embedded inside of it via JW player.

    In order to do so I need to link up an Amazon EC2 server with a software called Wowza that will stream the video to a JW embed.

    It's an interesting challenge and I need to do some more due diligence to figure out the best approach.

    I'm very proud of her!

    It was nice to be a guest at an event for once.

  • Read more, read more, read more.

     Jan 12, 2017

    Part of the reason I love having an activity sheet is that it holds me accountable to the goals I set.

    One of my goals is to read more and when my friend Andrew recommended these two books to me today, it seemed like a great opportunity to commit.

    I've purchased the first one 'Cracking the PM Interview' as an amazon kindle e-read and I'm going to try and read it on my phone while I'm at the gym.

    I read the first few pages and I can tell that it going to be a good read.

  • How to become a better Product Manager?

     Jan 11, 2017

    Being a product manager is my true role. I love driving products from concept to reality by connecting business, development, and design.

    But defining my role as a product manager can be difficult at times because every circumstance need something different. I am constantly having to adapt to the needs of my product, market, and teammates while balancing both budget and time.

    So I spent some time today researching more about how other people define the role of a product manager and the techniques they use to optimize their effectiveness.

    I found a lot of stuff, but one thing that I really like is this graphic.

    It does a very good job of breaking down the areas a PM is involved with and the responsibilities within each area of focus.

    I'm going to continue to soak up more knowledge and use the insights to start applying for roles as a PM.

  • Learning Gulp and first development for my portfolio

     Jan 10, 2017

    Gulp is a javascript task runner that helps automate tasks like bundling code and minifying images/gifs etc.

    Because my personal site will have a lot of heavy imagery, I decided to use gulp to build my personal site so that it's fast and snappy.

    I like it's plugin/modular infrastructure and the fact that it uses sass by default.

    On another note, the site design continues to change as I show people and get feedback. I'm think I'm goint to adjust my user flow so that there are individual pages for each project.

    It's cool to see how it changes day over day.

  • Updated design/experience for my personal site

     Jan 9, 2017

    I spent time today refining the purpose, vision, and design for my personal site.

    Highlighting my frontend work is a priority, so I've made it easy to access my work from a fixed sidebar on the right.

    I'm also going to make the images interactive. When a visitor hovers over one of the designs, it will trigger an accompanying video that will show engagements like hover to play or chopping a video.

    It is definitely a thought provoking process breaking down what's important and I'm excited to see it take shape.

  • Conducting problem interviews for Stash

     Jan 8, 2017

    Products need to solve problems. Whether it's telling you the time or autonomously driving you to work, products are created to solve a human problem.

    Today, Osebo and I interviewed a bio-med engineering masters student named Mishi.

    She was super nice and gave us a lot of great insight into her daily experience of discovering and saving online. Her go-to service is/was Tumblr, but it's gotten really cluttered and difficult for her to easily revisit her favorite content.

    The conversation was extremely helpful in identifying where her painpoints lie and how we can shape Stash's experience to solve her problems.

    Talking with Mishi also gave us a better understanding of who our target audience is. I'm not going to draw any conclusions yet, but we're excited to conduct more interviews to see if there are any consistent patterns.

  • Collecting facts on climate change for an interactive infographic

     Jan 7, 2017

    One topic that has captured my attention recently is global warming. There is so much controversy surrounding the issue, but there is no denying that human carbon emissions are causing alarming outcomes.

    Even though climate change has been gaining media coverage, people still seem to be unaware of the long term consequences from our current carbon output or don't care enough to make changes in their daily lives.

    I want to do my part to help inform others about the realities of global warming by creating a interactive inforgraphic about climate change.

    I've started collecting research and here are some of the mind-boggling facts that I found:

    • Every single day, 70 million tons of carbon dioxide are released into the earth‚Äôs atmosphere. That‚Äôs 1.4 billion pounds ‚Äì yesterday, today, tomorrow... [1]
    • Since temperature record-keeping began in 1880, the 10 warmest years on record have been in the past 12 years. [2]
    • 20 million tons of ice are lost per day from just one glacier in Greenland. This amount of daily ice lost is equal to the amount of water that New York City uses in an entire year. [3]
    • Over a hundred million people will be displaced by just a 1-yard rise in sea levels. Many scientists predict that the oceans will rise at least this much by 2100. [4]

    I don't want my children and grandchildren to never experience snow, or to have to wear medicical masks just to prevent them from inhaling smog. We only have one Earth, lets make changes to keep it habitable for future generations.
